vehicleUsageLabelHelp:
Commute to work or school (within the state): Regular commute to and from your place of employment or education.

Commute to work or school (outside the state): Driven out of state four or more times per month.

Business: For business purposes during the day in occupations that involve making regular sales or business calls.

Artisan: Used by a skilled craftsman who is not self-employed and who drives a private passenger auto, pickup or van to conduct business. Some examples of artisan use would be appliance repair, carpentry, plumbing, or other construction type occupations.

Pleasure: Not used on a regular basis for business, or for work or school commuting purposes.

Farming: Used primarily on a farm, ranch or orchard.

Transportation Network: Used in connection with any "transportation network" company using an internet-enabled computer application or platform to connect drivers of their own vehicles with paying customers needing transportation. Examples of such companies include Uber, Lyft, etc.
vinLabelHelp: A VIN number is generally 17 characters in length and does NOT contain the letters I and O, the numbers 1 or zero are used instead.
antiTheft1LabelHelp:
Alarm

Device that sounds an audible alarm that can be heard at a distance of at least 300 feet for a minimum of three minutes.
antiTheft2LabelHelp:
Manual Disabling Device

Device that disables the vehicle by making the fuel, ignition or starting system inoperative. This device type requires a separate manual step to engage the device.
antiTheft3LabelHelp:
Automatic Disabling Device

Device that disables the vehicle by making the fuel, ignition or starting system inoperative. This device type does not require a separate manual step to engage the device.
antiTheft5LabelHelp:
Lo Jack

Electronic homing device, using a radio frequency network used in conjunction with a participating police agency.
antiTheft6LabelHelp:
Teletrac

Electronic homing device, using a radio frequency network used in conjunction with a participating police agency
antiTheft7LabelHelp:
VIN Etching

Vehicle identification number (VIN) or other unique identifying symbol etched on the vehicle's window (i.e. vehicle's door glass, windshield and rear window).
promotionCodeLabelHelp: Mercury Insurance Group occasionally runs promotional giveaways. For additional promotion information please refer to the relevant terms and conditions.
driverFilingLabelHelp:
SR-22 or FR-44, also called Certificates of Financial Responsibility (CFR) are mandated by the state and provided by your auto insurance company to verify that you have auto insurance liability coverage.

Not everyone needs an SR-22 or FR-44. Usually, one is required by the court or mandated by the state for certain driving-related violations. Examples include: DUI convictions, reckless driving, accidents caused by uninsured drivers. If you need an SR-22 or FR-44, the courts or your state Motor Vehicle Department will notify you.
matureOrDefensiveDriverLabelHelp:
A discount may apply to drivers 55 years of age or older.To qualify the driver must:

  1. Have received a driver improvement course certificate within three years from a certified school that meets the standards of the State Department of Transportation, and
  2. Had no at fault accidents or traffic convictions since completing the course.

The discount is not applicable if the course is taken as punishment from a moving violation.
goodStudentNoLabelHelp:
A discount may apply to single full-time students (minimum of 12 units for undergraduate and 8 units for graduate) under the age of 23. To qualify the driver must attend high school, college, or vocational school and

  1. Be on the Dean's list; or
  2. In the top 20% of their class; or
  3. Have a grade average of "B" or better average; or
  4. Have a 3.0 or higher grade point average
pipClaimsCountLabelHelp: Personal Injury Protection (PIP) claims are claims filed with an insurance company made specifically for compensation of medical expenses and lost wages due to accidents involving the named insured, a dependent resident relative, or other occupants of the vehicle, regardless of fault.
salvageAndModificationsHelp: Modified/Damaged: A vehicle that has been upgraded with aftermarket parts and/or components or has existing damage, including broken glass.
FilingFeeLabelHelp:
Driver Filing Fee

A fee required for filing proof of financial responsibility with the state.
InstallmentFeeLabelHelp:
Installment Fees

Fees associated with paying your premium in installments.
HurricaneFeeLabelHelp:
FHCF Fee

This fee is a percentage of your automobile premium and is required by the state of Florida to support the Florida Hurricane Catastrophe Fund (FHCF).
PALiabilityCov_MIGHelpHelp: Bodily Injury and Property Damage cover damages if you injure someone or their property in an auto accident. For example $50,000/$100,000/$50,000 means you have coverage of $50,000 per person up to a maximum of $100,000 per accident if you injure someone, and $50,000 to cover damage of their property.
PAMedPayCov_MIGHelpHelp:
Medical provides coverage for reasonable medical expenses and/or funeral expenses made necessary due to an accident.
#more Learn more #more
PAMedPayCov_MIGHelpHelpMore1: Medical coverage pays reasonable medical and/or funeral expenses, made necessary due to an accident, for you and other persons occupying your auto. The coverage is provided regardless of fault. This coverage may be excess to other coverage you already own, and is subject to reimbursement under certain conditions specified in detail in the policy.
PAPipCovFL_MIGHelpHelp:
Personal Injury Protection provides coverage for reasonable medical expenses, lost wages and other related expenses.
#more Learn more #more
PAPipCovFL_MIGHelpHelpMore1:
Personal Injury Protection (PIP), also known as No-Fault coverage, provides coverage for you, your dependent resident relatives, and your passengers for injuries sustained in an accident, regardless of fault, up to the limits of your policy. PIP also covers you while in someone else's vehicle, or if you suffer an injury involving a motor vehicle as a pedestrian or bicyclist. PIP also covers your resident children if an injury is sustained while riding a school bus. The minimum PIP coverage required by law is $10,000. PIP coverage pays 80% of reasonable medical expenses, 60% of lost wages, reasonable expenses for replacement services such as child care, housekeeping or yard work, and a $5,000 death benefit.

If you select PIP with a deductible for the Named Insured, the deductible will only apply to the Named Insured and his/her spouse. If you select PIP with a deductible for the Name Insured and dependent Resident Relatives, the deductible will apply to the Named Insured, spouse, and all dependent resident relatives.

If the Wage Loss Exclusion is selected the Named Insured, spouse and dependent resident relatives will be excluded from receiving benefits for loss of gross income and loss of earning capacity.
PAComprehensiveCov_MIGHelpHelp: Comprehensive coverage pays to repair damages to your vehicle that are not caused by a collision, such as theft, fire, vandalism and hail. Payment for damages are subject to a deductible.
PACollisionCov_MIGHelpHelp: If you're in an auto accident, regardless of who is at fault, collision insurance provides protection to replace or repair your vehicle. Payment for damages is subject to a deductible.
PARentalCov_MIGHelpHelp: Rental car coverage will reimburse you for the rental of a vehicle from a qualified rental agency while an insured vehicle is being repaired due to a covered loss. The coverage is subject to a maximum daily amount for a specified limited period of time.
PARoadSideAssistance_MIGHelpHelp: Roadside Assistance can only be added to vehicles with Collision coverage. Mercury's Roadside Assistance provider offers covered services such as towing, locksmith services, battery jump-start, and flat tire change at the place where the vehicle was disabled (limitations and #more exclusions #more may apply).
PARoadSideAssistance_MIGHelpHelpMore1:
1. Routine maintenance of an insured auto;
  2. Labor not related to the disablement;
  3. Installation of products or materials not related to the disablement;
  4. Labor or repair work performed at a service station, garage or repair shop;
  5. Towing from a service station, garage or repair shop;
  6. Tire repair;
  7. Towing from entrapment in snow, mud, water or sand, more than 100 feet from a public road or highway;
  8. Disablement that occurs on road not regularly maintained, or on sand beaches, open fields, or areas designated as impassable due to construction, weather or earth movement;
  9. Towing related to impoundment, abandonment, illegal parking or other violations of law;
  10. Storage charges;
  11. Mounting or removing snow tires or chains; or
  12. Assistance with jacks, levelers or awnings on a motor home.
PAUMBICovFL_MIGHelpHelp:
Uninsured Motorist (UM) coverage provides bodily injury coverage for you, your resident relatives and the passengers in your covered vehicle. This coverage only applies if it is determined that the other driver is at fault and has insufficient or no liability coverage.

Within UM you may purchase one of two types of coverage-Stacked UM or Non-stacked UM.

Stacked UM coverage- The limits for each vehicle listed on your policy may be combined to determine the total amount of UM coverage.

Non-stacked UM coverage- The limits for each vehicle may not be combined, your UM coverage is based on the limits for only one vehicle.
isSalvagedVehicleLabelHelp: A wrecked or damaged vehicle that has been previously deemed a total loss.
tnDriverLabelHelp: Transportation Network: Used in connection with any "transportation network" company using an internet-enabled computer application or platform to connect drivers of their own vehicles with paying customers needing transportation. Examples of such companies include Uber, Lyft, etc.
